summary.title: eTorch Threat Model
summary.description: The eTorch system is an intelligent IoT lighting solution consisting of WiFi-enabled eTorch devices, optional field gateways, mobile and Windows control applications, an embedded web management interface, and a cloud portal hosted by eHomeSystems. Users and administrators can control lighting, schedules, firmware updates, and device groups locally and remotely using HTTP/HTTPS. The system also supports optional voice control via third-party voice assistants and operates with limited functionality when offline using locally cached schedules.

threats.title: Spoofing – Ordinary User Identity Impersonation
threats.description: An attacker may impersonate a legitimate ordinary user by stealing credentials or session tokens, allowing unauthorized access to system functions.
threats.mitigation: Strong authentication mechanisms, multi-factor authentication (MFA), secure password policies, and session validation.

threats.title: Repudiation – User Actions Not Properly Logged
threats.description: An ordinary user may deny performing certain actions such as configuration changes or control commands if sufficient logging and audit trails are not in place.
threats.mitigation: Implement comprehensive audit logging, secure log storage, timestamps, and user action tracking with integrity protection.

threats.title: Administrator identity spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may impersonate an administrator by stealing credentials or exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, gaining unauthorized access to administrative functions and system configuration.
threats.mitigation: Implement strong authentication mechanisms such as multi-factor authentication (MFA), enforce strong password policies, limit administrative access, and monitor login attempts with logging and alerts.

threats.title: Administrator action repudiation
threats.description: An administrator could deny performing sensitive actions such as configuration changes or user management if proper logging and audit mechanisms are not in place.
threats.mitigation: Enable detailed audit logging, ensure logs are tamper-resistant, associate all administrative actions with authenticated identities, and retain logs for forensic analysis.

threats.title: Spoofing – Windows Control Application
threats.description:
An attacker could impersonate a legitimate Windows Control Application
or a valid user session, allowing unauthorized access to system
functions and backend APIs.
threats.mitigation:
Use strong authentication mechanisms such as certificate-based
authentication, secure session tokens, device binding,
and multi-factor authentication.

threats.title: Tampering – Windows Control Application
threats.description:
An attacker could modify or manipulate commands sent from the
Windows Control Application to the backend API, potentially altering
device behavior or system configuration.
threats.mitigation:
Implement message integrity checks, request signing,
input validation, and secure communication channels (HTTPS/TLS)
to prevent command manipulation.

threats.title: Repudiation – Windows Control Application actions
threats.description:
A user or attacker may deny having performed certain actions
or sent commands through the Windows Control Application
due to insufficient logging and audit trails.
threats.mitigation:
Enable detailed audit logging, timestamped event records,
user identification, and secure log storage to ensure
accountability and non-repudiation.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – Windows Control Application data exposure
threats.description:
Sensitive information such as user credentials, device identifiers,
or control commands may be exposed through the Windows Control
Application due to insecure storage, logging, or transmission.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit, enforce secure
authentication mechanisms, minimize local data storage,
and restrict access to sensitive logs.

threats.title: Denial of Service – Windows Control Application request flooding
threats.description:
The Windows Control Application may be overwhelmed by excessive or
malicious requests, causing service degradation or preventing
legitimate users from controlling devices.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting, request throttling, input validation,
and backend monitoring to detect and block abusive traffic.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege – Mobile Control Application unauthorized access
threats.description:
An attacker may exploit weaknesses in the Mobile Control Application
to gain higher privileges, allowing unauthorized control of devices
or access to administrative functions.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strict role-based access control, validate permissions on
the backend, apply secure authentication tokens, and perform
regular security testing of the mobile application.

threats.title: Repudiation – User actions not properly logged
threats.description:
A user may deny performing actions within the system if sufficient
logging and auditing mechanisms are not in place, making it difficult
to trace changes or investigate incidents.
threats.mitigation:
Implement comprehensive audit logging, including timestamps,
user identifiers, and action details. Protect logs from tampering
and ensure logs are regularly reviewed.

threats.title: Tampering – API request manipulation
threats.description: An attacker may tamper with API requests between the mobile control application and the cloud backend, modifying parameters or payloads to execute unauthorized actions or alter device states.
threats.mitigation: Use HTTPS with TLS encryption, request signing, input validation, and server-side authorization checks to prevent modification of API requests.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – API data leakage
threats.description: Sensitive information such as user data, device identifiers, or authentication tokens may be exposed through API responses between the mobile application and the cloud backend.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all API communications, minimize data returned in responses, apply proper access control, and avoid exposing sensitive information in logs or error messages.

threats.title: Denial of Service – API rate exhaustion
threats.description: An attacker may overwhelm the API endpoints with excessive requests, exhausting server resources and preventing legitimate users from accessing the system.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting, request throttling, IP-based blocking, and Web Application Firewall (WAF) protections to detect and mitigate traffic floods.

threats.title: Tampering – API request parameters manipulated
threats.description: An attacker may modify API request parameters while data is transmitted between the client applications and the cloud backend, leading to unauthorized actions or corrupted data.
threats.mitigation: Use HTTPS with TLS encryption, implement request validation, apply message integrity checks, and enforce strict server-side input validation.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – Sensitive data exposed over API
threats.description: Sensitive information such as user credentials, device identifiers, or configuration data may be exposed during API communication between client applications and the cloud backend.
threats.mitigation: Enforce TLS encryption, avoid sending sensitive data in URLs, use secure authentication tokens, and apply data minimization principles.

threats.title: Denial of Service – API request flooding
threats.description: An attacker could overwhelm the API endpoint with a large number of requests, causing service degradation or unavailability for legitimate users.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting, request throttling, API gateways, and monitoring to detect and block abnormal traffic patterns.

threats.title: Tampering with User & Device Data
threats.description: An attacker may modify user or device data during read or write operations, leading to unauthorized changes in system state or configuration.
threats.mitigation: Implement strong access controls, input validation, integrity checks, database auditing, and encryption to prevent unauthorized data modification.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – User & Device Data
threats.description:
Sensitive user and device information may be exposed during read/write operations
between the cloud backend and the database if access controls or encryption
are improperly implemented.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit, enforce strict access control,
apply least-privilege permissions, and log and monitor database access.

threats.title: Denial of Service – Database Access Flooding
threats.description:
An attacker may flood the backend or database with excessive read/write requests,
causing resource exhaustion and preventing legitimate users from accessing
the system.
threats.mitigation:
Apply rate limiting, request throttling, backend load balancing,
database connection limits, and monitoring with alerts for abnormal traffic.

threats.title: Tampering with admin configuration commands
threats.description: Admin configuration commands could be modified during transmission, allowing an attacker to change system settings or inject malicious configurations.
threats.mitigation: Use HTTPS/TLS encryption, integrity checks, strict server-side validation of configuration commands, and secure authentication for admin operations.

threats.title: Sensitive data exposure during data transfer
threats.description: Sensitive user or device information may be exposed during data transmission if communication is intercepted, logged improperly, or misconfigured, especially when crossing trust boundaries
threats.mitigation: Enforce HTTPS/TLS encryption, apply proper access controls, avoid exposing sensitive data in responses or logs, and validate secure configuration of backend services.

threats.title: Denial of Service via excessive requests
threats.description:
An attacker may overwhelm the service by sending a large number of requests,
causing performance degradation or service unavailability for legitimate users.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting, request throttling, traffic monitoring, and
denial-of-service protection mechanisms such as firewalls or load balancers.

threats.title: Tampering – Web management request parameters modified
threats.description:
An attacker could tamper with web management request parameters sent between
the Embedded Web Management UI and the cloud portal, potentially modifying
device configuration or user data.
threats.mitigation:
Use HTTPS with TLS, server-side input validation, integrity checks,
and authentication to ensure requests cannot be modified in transit.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – Web management data exposure
threats.description:
Sensitive information such as user credentials or device configuration
data could be exposed through web management requests if not properly
protected.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce HTTPS with TLS, avoid sensitive data in URLs, apply authentication
and authorization, and sanitize responses.

threats.title: Denial of Service – Web management endpoint abuse
threats.description:
An attacker could flood the web management interface with excessive
requests, causing service degradation or unavailability for legitimate users.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting, request throttling, CAPTCHA for admin actions,
and monitoring with alerting for abnormal traffic patterns.

threats.title: Tampering – User command parameters manipulated
threats.description:
An attacker may modify user command parameters sent from the mobile application,
leading to unauthorized device control or altered system behavior.
threats.mitigation:
Use strong input validation, request integrity checks, authentication tokens,
and secure communication channels (HTTPS).

threats.title: Information Disclosure – Sensitive data exposed in user commands
threats.description:
Sensitive user information such as credentials or control data may be exposed
during transmission of user commands from the mobile application.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt data in transit using HTTPS, avoid transmitting sensitive data in plain
text, and apply proper access control and data minimization.

threats.title: Information Disclosure – Sensitive data exposed in user commands
threats.description:
Sensitive user information such as credentials or control data may be exposed
during transmission of user commands from the mobile or web application.
threats.mitigation:
Use HTTPS for all communications, encrypt sensitive data in transit, apply
proper authentication, and avoid exposing sensitive data in requests.

threats.title: Denial of Service – Excessive user command requests
threats.description:
An attacker or misbehaving client may send excessive user commands that overwhelm
the application, leading to service unavailability for legitimate users.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting, request throttling, monitoring, and automatic blocking
of abusive clients to prevent service exhaustion.
